prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 613 Band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: One pointing, CO(3-2), HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875 GHz bandwidth per baseband, and velocity resolution of 4MHz ~ 3.5 km/s (FDM). When this velocity resolution is too high, we will smooth the spectra to 10km/s, especially in the HCN/HCO+ lines, and to search for faint velocity wings (expected to extend to 200km/s maximum) that would be signatures of outflows.

We want to map the CO(3-2) line (and HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)) in one pointing, centered on the nucleus and covering the whole nuclear disk and ring (diameter is smaller than the FOV=18). For the high spatial resolution of 0.14, we require the extended configuration C36-5 in Band 7. Because of large velocity gradients, at a given velocity, so for each channel map, the LAS will not be larger than 2 arcsec. Given the large velocity gradients in this nucleus, and the clumpy nature of the dense gas and dust, we expect no extended emission in any given channel map, and thus do not require ACA.

The central CO(2-1) profiles obtained with the SEST 22 beam gave signals of 200mK, and we can expect signals of more than 7K at high resolution in CO(3-2), given the very contrasted structure found in the HST dust images. In 30min of integration time, we can reach an rms of 0.5K (or 1mJy at the 0.14 scale). The maxima of the intensity will be comfortably detected (S/N>10), and we need to spend about 1hour on this source to take into account calibrations. The weaker lines of HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3), probing the densest clouds, will be detected with S/N=4. Also, 1 hour will allow for a correct sampling of the UV plane. We can expect a continuum of at least 10 mJy at 0.87mm, which will be detected with S/N much larger than 10.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 1326 Band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: One pointing CO(3-2), HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875 GHz bandwidth per baseband, and velocity resolution of 4MHz ~ 3.5 km/s (FDM). When this velocity resolution is too high, we will smooth the spectra to 10km/s, especially in the HCN/HCO+ lines, and to search for faint velocity wings (expected to extend to 200km/s maximum) that would be signatures of outflows.

We want to map the CO(3-2) line (and HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)) in one pointing, centered on the nucleus and covering the whole nuclear disk and ring (diameter is smaller than the FOV=18). For the high spatial resolution of 0.14, we require the extended configuration C36-5 in Band 7. Because of large velocity gradients, at a given velocity, so for each channel map, the LAS will not be larger than 2 arcsec. Given the large velocity gradients in this nucleus, and the clumpy nature of the dense gas and dust, we expect no extended emission in any given channel map, and thus do not require ACA.

The central CO(2-1) profiles obtained with the SEST 22 beam gave signals of 40mK, and we can expect signals of more than 7K at high resolution in CO(3-2), given the very contrasted structure found in the HST dust images. In 30min of integration time, we can reach an rms of 0.5K (or 1mJy at the 0.14 scale). The maxima of the intensity will be comfortably detected (S/N>10), and we need to spend about 1hour on this source to take into account calibrations. The weaker lines of HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3), probing the densest clouds, will be detected with S/N=4. Also, 1 hour will allow for a correct sampling of the UV plane. We can expect a continuum of at least 5 mJy at 0.87mm, which will be detected with S/N much larger than 10.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 1365 Band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mosaic of 13 points, CO(3-2), HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875 GHz bandwidth per baseband, and velocity resolution of 4MHz ~ 3.5 km/s (FDM). When this velocity resolution is too high, we will smooth the spectra to 10km/s, especially in the HCN/HCO+ lines, and to search for faint velocity wings (expected to extend to 200km/s maximum) that would be signatures of outflows.

We want to map the CO(3-2) line (and HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)) in a 36x18 mosaic, centered on the nucleus and covering the whole nuclear disk (diameter is about 30). For the high spatial resolution of 0.14, we require the extended configuration C36-5 in Band 7. Because of large velocity gradients, at a given velocity, so for each channel map, the LAS will not be larger than 2 arcsec. Given the large velocity gradients in this nucleus, and the clumpy nature of the dense gas and dust, we expect no extended emission in any given channel map, and thus do not require ACA.

The central CO(2-1) profiles obtained with the SEST 22 beam gave signals of 900mK, and we can expect signals of more than 60K at high resolution in CO(3-2), given the very contrasted structure found in the HST dust images. In 30min of integration time, we can reach an rms of 1.5K (or 3mJy at the 0.14 scale). The maxima of the intensity will be comfortably detected (S/N>10), and we need to spend about 1hour on this source to take into account calibrations. The weaker lines of HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3), probing the densest clouds, will be detected with S/N=4. Also, 1 hour will allow for a correct sampling of the UV plane. We can expect a continuum of at least 50 mJy at 0.87mm, which will be detected with S/N much larger than 10.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875 GHz bandwidth per baseband, and velocity resolution of 4MHz ~ 3.5 km/s (FDM). Given the large velocity gradients in this nucleus, and the clumpy nature of the dense gas and dust, we expect no extended emission in any given channel map, and thus do not require ACA.

The central CO(2-1) profiles obtained with the SEST 22 beam gave signals of 380mK, and we can expect signals of more than 20K at high resolution in CO(3-2), given the very contrasted structure found in the HST dust images. The maxima of the intensity will be comfortably detected (S/N>10), and we need to spend about 1hour on this source to take into account calibrations. The weaker lines of HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3), probing the densest clouds, will be detected with S/N=4. Also, 1 hour will allow for a correct sampling of the UV plane. prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 1808 Band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: One pointing in CO(3-2), HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875 GHz bandwidth per baseband, and velocity resolution of 4MHz ~ 3.5 km/s (FDM). When this velocity resolution is too high, we will smooth the spectra to 10km/s, especially in the HCN/HCO+ lines, and to search for faint velocity wings (expected to extend to 200km/s maximum) that would be signatures of outflows.

We want to map the CO(3-2) line (and HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)) in one pointing, centered on the nucleus and covering the whole nuclear disk and ring (diameter is smaller than the FOV=18). For the high spatial resolution of 0.14, we require the extended configuration C36-5 in Band 7. Because of large velocity gradients, at a given velocity, so for each channel map, the LAS will not be larger than 2 arcsec. Given the large velocity gradients in this nucleus, and the clumpy nature of the dense gas and dust, we expect no extended emission in any given channel map, and thus do not require ACA.

The central CO(2-1) profiles obtained with the SEST 22 beam gave signals of 840mK, and we can expect signals of more than 40K at high resolution in CO(3-2), given the very contrasted structure found in the HST dust images. In 30min of integration time, we can reach an rms of 1K (or 2mJy at the 0.14 scale). The maxima of the intensity will be comfortably detected (S/N>10), and we need to spend about 1hour on this source to take into account calibrations. The weaker lines of HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3), probing the densest clouds, will be detected with S/N=4. Also, 1 hour will allow for a correct sampling of the UV plane. We can expect a continuum of at least 20 mJy at 0.87mm, which will be detected with S/N much larger than 10.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The effects of feedback and fueling of active galactic nuclei (AGN) play a fundamental role in galaxy evolution, through quenching star-formation activity and growing massive black holes in the centers of galaxies. Our NUclei of GAlaxies (NUGA) study of molecular gas in ~20 AGN circumnuclear regions on 100 pc scales has shown that nested, kinematically decoupled bars are able to effectively funnel gas into the nucleus, although only in 1 out of 3 cases. It is possible that different time-scales and episodic fueling are to blame, or that AGN (and supernovae) feedback halts the process. To further characterize fueling and feedback in AGN, we have defined a small sample of AGN that spans a factor of 100 in AGN power and a factor of 10 in star-formation rate. We propose to map the morphology and kinematics of the cold dense gas in five nearby Seyfert/LINER nuclei at the unprecedented spatial resolution of 0.14" (8-16 pc). We will quantify the AGN fueling by measuring torques on the gas with our well-tested algorithm, and characterize molecular outflows as well as compare their properties with near-infrared SINFONI spectral cubes already in hand.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00208.S, PI F. Combes, NGC1433 and NGC1566 2011.0.00083.S, PI S. Garcia-Burillo, NGC 1068
